repnme.cdata!: Nigeria - Community Based Poverty Reduction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Community Based Poverty
            Reduction Project (CPRP) for Nigeria were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            community-based initiatives need to be integrated and
            coordinated with the broader poverty reduction strategy of
            the government in order to effectively tackle poverty
            reduction. The CPRP is an example of a project that was
            likely more successful than the M&E data can possibly
            tell. Key indicators were regularly collected and used by
            state agencies to carry out desk and field assessments of
            proposals, as well as the selection and funding of
            micro-projects, and to monitor the realization of the
            community infrastructure. But very little was collected on
            targeting, the participatory process, and impacts on the
            well-being of the communities. Community-development
            projects, when properly designed, have the potential of
            addressing the needs of community members who are
            traditionally marginalized or not adequately represented.

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Building macroeconomic stability
            and delivering services for the poor

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            building macroeconomic stability and delivering services for
            the poor in Nigeria. Despite Nigeria’s strong economic track
            record, poverty is significant, and reducing it would
            require strong non-oil growth and a focus on human
            development. National Urban Water Sector Reform Project
            addressed the fundamental causes of the problem, and ensured
            improved governance at all levels. As a result, projects in
            various sectors had seen positive results in education,
            health, and the delivery of clean water in the country.

repnme.cdata!: Nigeria - Community Based Poverty Reduction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Community Based Poverty
            Reduction Project for Nigeria were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower performance
            was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: local
            government areas (LGAs) are the closest link to government,
            and any project that is oriented towards capacity
            development at the grassroots level must make provision for
            involvement of the LGAs. The project selection method under
            the Community Poverty Reduction Project (CPRP) gave
            communities voice and allowed them to participate in the
            decision making process with the ability to conceive
            communal goals, prioritize projects, and select projects for
            funding through participatory methods. LGAs should be
            encouraged to follow this method of selection of capital
            projects for communities such that beneficiary communities
            are given the opportunity to participate in decisions
            concerning annual budgets for LGAs. With the CPRP approach,
            communities can be effective partners with government and
            LGAs in reducing their poverty. The partnering of the LGAs
            with the CPRP to staff the schools and the clinics under the
            project is one of the success stories of the project. Future
            projects should consider this kind of partnership to be a
            standing arrangement under the project. The project
            demonstrated that, with proper sensitization women can fully
            participate in community-driven development (CDD) projects.
            As anticipated in the design and the target set for the
            project, the majority (about 70 percent) of the project
            beneficiaries were women. Some of the non-beneficiary
            communities have gone ahead and replicated the financing
            structure of the CPRP and have started self-help projects in
            their communities. This is considered a positive development.

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Community Based Poverty Reduction
            Project : additional financing

abstracts.cdata!:
This Project Paper seeks the approval of
            the Executive Directors to provide additional financing to
            the Federal Republic of Nigeria, Community-Based Poverty
            Reduction Project. The additional financing will help
            finance the costs associated with a financing gap for
            micro-projects that are underway and are therefore
            prerequisite in fulfilling the expectations of the poor
            communities. The additional financing to the current
            participating States to complete the original project
            activities will therefore: (i) ensure that all
            micro-projects are completed at the close of the project;
            (ii) increase the project's impact and development
            effectiveness; and (iii) serve as a bridging fund - pending
            the commencement of the National Community Driven
            Development Program (National CDD) as a follow-on to the
            Community-based Poverty Reduction Project (CPRP). The
            National CDD would build on the CPRP, scaling it up both
            geographically to cover other states, and thematically to
            cover additional activities. Implementation, financial and
            procurement arrangements will remain the same. The
            indicators for the additional financing will be the same as
            in the current project but the targets are to be revised as
            a result of the increased funding for micro-projects. The
            expected outcomes from the additional funding will be: (a)
            improved services and infrastructure in participating poor
            communities; (b) increased capacity of government to
            support, monitor, and evaluate poverty reduction activities;
            and (c) increased capacity at state level for implementing
            community-driven development, and for financing
            community-generated projects.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Nigeria Community Based Poverty
            Reduction Project became effective in September 2001. The
            beneficiary states are Abia, Ekiti, Cross River, Kebbi,
            Kogi, and Yobe state. Six other states have just joined the
            second phase of the project with AfDB supporting four of
            them. They are Delta, Ebonyi, Gombe, Kwara, Osun and Zamfara
            States. As of January 2005 over 800 communities in the
            first-phase states have successfully implemented and
            completed 1,017 sub-projects that include 348 school
            projects; 350 water projects, 90 road projects, 90 health
            projects, 72 electricity projects and 67 other projects such
            as environmental protection, training centers and commercial markets.
